intro: Silene holosteifolia, commonly known as the redstem catchfly, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It is a member of the Caryophyllaceae family, characterized by its showy, pink to red flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in moist, open habitats such as meadows and woodlands, reaching heights of up to 60 cm. Its leaves are lance-shaped and slightly hairy, while its stems are often reddish in color. Silene holosteifolia plays a role in supporting local pollinators and is of interest in ecological and botanical studies.
